</summary>

[When is the action happening?]: The action is happening over a long period of time, potentially decades, as the misfolded proteins accumulate and propagate in the brain.

[Where is the action happening?]: The action is happening in the brain, specifically in the central nervous system, where the misfolded proteins are aggregating and propagating.
</summary>

<summary>
[What is the main point?]: The study investigates the effect of interferon-based therapies on outcomes in African American patients with chronic hepatitis C (CHC) and finds that achieving a sustained virological response (SVR) protects them from cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC).

[Why is it happening?]: The study aims to understand the progression of liver disease in African Americans, who are twice as likely to be infected with HCV and have historically had lower response rates to approved interferon-based therapies.

[Who is involved?]: The study involves 346 African American patients with CHC, genotype 1, who were followed for an average of 8 years.

[When is the action happening?]: The patients were first seen between 1995 and 2008, and the study followed them until 2012-2013 or the development of HCC.

[Where is the action happening?]: The study was conducted at the Wayne State University Physician Group (UPG) gastroenterology clinic.

<summary>

[Why is it happening?]: Methadone-induced [Ca]cyt deregulation is caused by improper functioning of mechanisms that directly control mitochondrial activity, leading to mitochondrial calcium overload and permeability transition pore (MPTP) formation.

[Who is involved?]: The study involves SH-SY5Y cells, a human neuroblastoma cell line, and various pharmacological agents such as methadone, oligomycin, FCCP, CGP37157, and cyclosporine A.

[Where is the action happening?]: The study is conducted in vitro, using SH-SY5Y cells cultured in a laboratory setting.
</summary>

[Who is involved?]: The study involves 462 eyes of 305 glaucoma patients and 62 eyes of 49 healthy controls.

However, patients often do not admit to smoking or provide inaccurate information, making it difficult to assess their smoking history.

[Who is involved?]: The Welsh Government, Higher Education Funding Council for Wales (HEFCW), Universities Wales, and other stakeholders in the higher education sector.
[When is the action happening?]: The review is ongoing, with a consultation on post-compulsory education and training (PCET) reforms having closed in summer 2018.
[Where is the action happening?]: Wales, UK.
</summary>
